stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>Family life and marriage - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>Youth - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p><i>Background</i>:<br> The Longitudinal Study of Young People in England (LSYPE), also known as Next Steps, commissioned by the Department for Children, Schools and Families (DCSF) (formerly the Department for Education and Skills (DfES)), is a major innovative panel study of young people. The study began in 2004, when its sample of young people were aged between 13 and 14. LSYPE is one of the main information sources for the formation and appraisal of policies relating to young people and will continue to be so for at least the next 10 years. The baseline data will be used to monitor the progress of the cohort group, evaluate the success of policies aimed at this group and provide an evidence base for further policy development. The study brings together data from a wide range of sources and reflects the variety of influences on learning and progression. Annual interviews obtain information from the young person and additional information from a main and second parent interview.<br> <br> <i>Objectives</i>:<br> The main objectives of the LSYPE are:<ul><li>to gather evidence about the transitions young people make from secondary and tertiary education or training to economic roles in early adulthood</li><li>to enhance the ability to monitor and evaluate the effects of existing policy and provide a strong information base for future policy development</li><li>to contextualise the implementation of new policies in terms of young people's current lives</li></ul><i>Conduct of the survey</i><br> Fieldwork for the first four waves was carried out by a consortium of contractors, comprising BMRB Social Research, GfK NOP (known as NOP World at the time Wave One of the survey was conducted) and Ipsos MORI (known as MORI at the time of Wave One). Interviews for the first four waves were conducted face-to-face. At Waves Five and Six, fieldwork was carried out by BMRB and GfK NOP only and a mixed mode approach was used; respondents could complete the interview online, over the telephone, or face-to-face as for the previous waves. Also, Wave Five was the first wave at which only the sampled young person was interviewed; previously, at least one of the sampled young person's parents/guardians had also been interviewed. This continued in Wave Six. Validation of the data collected and enhancement of the study at all waves has been undertaken by NatCen Social Research (formerly the National Centre for Social Research) for Waves One to Six and by the Department for Education for Wave Seven.<br> <br> <i>Variables available in the Secure Access version</i><br> The Secure Access version has been supplemented by linkage to the National Pupil Database (NPD). It also includes the following levels of geography for Wave One: Government Office Regions, Local Authority Districts, Super Output Areas (Lower Layer), and Local Learning and Skills Council areas.  Also included are Wave One urban/rural indicators, Income Deprivation Affecting Children Indices, Indices of Multiple Deprivation, as well as sensitive variables such as specialist school type and pupil level achievement data.<br> <br> When researchers are approved/accredited to access the Secure Access version of LSYPE, the End User Licence version of the study (SN 5545) will be automatically provided alongside.<br> <br> The second edition (May 2013) includes data files containing sensitive variables from across all seven waves (see 'Main Topics' below).<br/></abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Questionnaires for Waves One to Four gathered information on:<ul><li>the young person's family background</li><li>parental socio-economic status</li><li>personal characteristics</li><li>attitudes, experiences and behaviours</li><li>attainment in education</li><li>parental employment</li><li>income and family environment as well as local deprivation</li><li>the school(s) the young person attends/has attended</li><li>the young person's post-16 plans</ul></li>The questionnaire for Waves Five, Six and Seven consisted of two modules:<ul><li>Household Information Module: included questions on the young person's household situation and details of any persons living with them</li><li>Young Person Module: topics included demographics, attitudes to local area, activity history and current activity, jobs and training, qualifications being studied, higher education, attitudes to work and debt, childcare and caring responsibilities, young people Not in Education Employment or Training (NEET), Apprenticeships, information, advice and guidance, risk behaviours, relationships and sexuality, and own children.</ul></li>The additional 'Monthly Main Activity' dataset takes responses to the Activity History section of the questionnaire at Waves Four to Seven and synthesises this information into variables that represent a monthly time series running from September 2006 (two months after the respondents completed compulsory education) until May 2010 (the first month of interviews for Wave Seven). For each of the 45 months in this period, this file contains the respondent's derived 'main' activity which is classified as one of Education, Employment, Apprenticeship/Training or Unemployed/Inactive (NEET).<br> <br> In order to deal with the large number of variables in the study, the dataset has been split into more manageable subsets based on the type of respondent being examined and the source of the information. More information on the composition of each wave of the study and how to link data from different waves together can be found in the User Guide.<br> <br> The second edition of the Secure Access version of the study includes sensitive variables covering the following topics:<br> Family background:<ul><li>Wave One: qualifications of parents</li><li>Wave Two: social security benefits and pensions, qualifications of parents</li><li>Wave Three: young person in care</li><li>Wave Four: qualifications of parents, ethnic group of parents, other languages spoken in household</li><li>Wave Five: household size and housing tenure/type for young person, parents' age and employment</li></ul>History:<ul><li>Wave Four: young persons' birth history and residence in the UK</li></ul>Young person:<ul><li>Wave One: ethnic group, disabilities</li><li>Wave Two: disabilities</li><li>Wave Three: sources of income</li><li>Wave Four: special education needs, ethnic group, behaviour, child care arrangements for young person and young person's children, studies and qualifications, educational grant applications</li><li>Wave Five: fields of study, qualifications, career aspirations, difficulties finding job, occupation, benefits claimed, child care arrangements</li><li>Wave Six: fields of study, qualifications, reasons for not going to university, wages/income, benefits claimed, health problems, contraception used, sexuality, child bearing, child care arrangements</li><li>Wave Seven: applying for higher education, studies and qualifications, training, apprenticeships, gap years, careers advice, starting to work, employment, wages, unemployment, difficulties finding job, health problems, sexual behaviour, living with parents, recreational drug use, bullying, child care arrangements, benefits claimed</li></ul></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="2004-03-01T00:00:00Z">March 2004</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" date="2010-10-01T00:00:00Z">October 2010</timePrd>         <collDate>Wave One: 30 March - 19 October 2004. Wave Two: 18 April - 18 September 2005. Wave Three: 21 April - 28 September 2006. Wave Four: 12 June - 14 October 2007. Wave Five: 3 June - 28 October 2008. Wave Six: 12 May - 14 October 2009. Wave Seven: 18 May - 12 October 2010.</collDate>         <nation>England</nation>         <geogUnit>Government Office Regions</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Local Learning and Skills Council Areas</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Local Authority Districts</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Super Output Areas (Lower Layer)</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Young people in Year 9 (or equivalent) in schools in England in February 2004 (born between 1 September 1989 and 31 August 1990). For Waves One to Four, at least one of the young person's parents/guardians/carers were also interviewed. For Waves Five, Six and Seven, only the young person was interviewed. See documentation for further details.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Longitudinal/panel/cohort</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Data from Waves One to Seven are included at present.</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>BMRB. Social Research</dataCollector>         <dataCollector>GfK NOP</dataCollector>         <dataCollector>Ipsos MORI</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <sampProc>See documentation for further details.</sampProc>         <deviat>15,770 households at Wave One, 13,539 households at Wave Two, 12,439 households at Wave Three, 11,449 households (plus 352 households in ethnic boost sample) at Wave Four, 10,430 households at Wave Five, 9,799 households at Wave Six, and 8,682 households at Wave Seven.</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Telephone interview; Self-completion</collMode>         <collMode>For Waves One to Four, face-to-face interviews (with a self-completion element) were conducted; for Waves Five, Six and Seven, the young person could choose to complete the interview face-to-face, via telephone, or online (web-based).</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Secure data</specPerm>         <restrctn>Registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor will be informed about usage. Controlled data requirements and conditions also apply. Further information is available from <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/accesssecurelab.aspx'>Access to the Secure Lab</a>. In addition, the Service is required to request explicit permission from the data owner prior to providing the researcher with access to the data.<br>Available to UK HE/FE applicants only. <p>Please note:<br>Since these data are more sensitive and/or pose a higher risk of disclosure than data made available under the standard End User Licence or under a Special Licence, they are not available for download but may be accessed through Secure Access. Access requires accreditation as an ESRC Accredited Researcher, completion of face-to-face training, and agreement to the Secure Access's <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176858/ukda140_sds_sdsagreement_public.pdf'>User Agreement</a> and <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176861/UKDA142_SDS_SecurityBreaches_public.pdf'>Breaches Penalties Policy</a>. This is to ensure that the guarantee of confidentiality given to survey respondents is protected. Applications are screened by the UK Data Archive and the individual or institution having ownership of the data (or their designated authority), and access is only granted to those researchers requiring data for statistical research purposes and who can justify their need for the data. Users who obtain access to these data are also required to read and follow the <a href='http://www.data-archive.ac.uk/media/132701/UKDA171-SS-MicrodataHandling.pdf'> Microdata Handling and Security: Guide to Good Practice</a>.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relPubl>Department for Education (2011) <i>Youth Cohort Study and Longitudinal Study of Young People in England: the activities and experiences of 19 year olds: England 2010</I>, Sheffield: Department for Education.
